title: Dreams of the garden city blossoming with pink
text:
Dreams of the garden city blossoming with pink MONIQUE STEELE Last updated 16:46, February 8 2017 123RF.COM 
Should we line central Christchurch streets with cherry blossom trees? 
On a warm summer's day, tourists and families walk down Christchurch's Colombo St, buskers jam easy listening tunes and local vendors sell fresh produce grown just down the road. 
This is the vision Christchurch architect Jay Van Lent has for what he calls the "cross of the city" â€“ Colombo and Worcester streets. 
Christchurch born and raised, Arko Exterior Architecture owner Van Lent wants to beautify the CBD, lining the streets with cherry blossom trees and establishing a farmers' market in the city centre. MONIQUE STEELE/FAIRFAX NZ 
Christchurch landscape architect Jay van Lent beside his aerial map of the "cross of the CBD" - the intersection of Colombo and Worcester streets, centred by the Christ Church Cathedral. 
In Van Lent's New Regent St office hangs a two-metre cross, an aerial view of Colombo and Worcester streets with Christ Church Cathedral in the centre. 
About 400 pink cherry blossom trees line the streets in his plans, creating an archway of pink blossoms at street level, which Van Lent says will revitalise the CBD. SUPPLIED 
Arko landscape architect Jay van Lent's "cross of the CBD", which he dreams of lining with cherry blossoms. 
"It's something that would create such a character and history for the city," he said. 
"I think it would pull at the heart strings." 
He said he was unmotivated by any religious meanings of the cross, but bringing trees into the city made it the perfect place for a farmers' market. A year-round market around the Cathedral could be a "draw card for tourism" in the city. MONIQUE STEELE/FAIRFAX NZ 
Landscape architect Jay Van Lent dreams of turning Oxford Tce into the heart of the Avon River, adding flower beds and a wishing well. 
"Tourists come here and want to see that. This would be a great way for us to celebrate the city. Ad Feedback 
"It's going to help bring our community together." 
According to a quote from a Christchurch arborist company, it would cost about $400,000 for 400 trees to be transplanted, which Van Lent said was affordable in comparison to concrete costs. 
"For within $1 million, you have a cherry blossom cross throughout the city," he said. 
From his experience as a landscape architect, Christchurch residents wanted more trees and less concrete structures, especially in the city centre, he said. 
He said Christchurch Mayor Lianne Dalziel stopped by his office to see the cross design. 
"Lianne loved it . . . she wants trees in the city." 
Christchurch City Council head of parks Andrew Rutledge said the council was yet to commence planning for the revitalisation of Cathedral Square. 
"The council hasn't formally called for design ideas. . . . This plan is one person's vision of how they would like to see the city revitalised." 
He said it was too early to comment on the possible cost of the project. - Stuff
